column2: US: ; Tagalog: Lungsod Quezon [luŋˈsod ˈkɛson]; also known as QC or Kyusi) is a highly urbanized city and the most populous city in the Philippines. It was founded by and named after Manuel L. Quezon
column3: the 2nd President of the Philippines
column4: to replace Manila as the national capital.  The city was proclaimed as such in 1948
column5: though a significant number of government buildings remained in Manila. Quezon City held status as the official capital until 1976 when a presidential decree was issued to reinstate and designate Manila as the capital and Metro Manila as the seat of government.It is the largest city in terms of population and land area in Metro Manila
column6: the National Capital Region of the Philippines. Quezon City is not located in
column7: and should not be confused with the province of Quezon
column8: which was also named after the president.

column1: Quezon City hosts a number of government offices
column2: the most important of which are the Batasang Pambansa Complex (the seat of the House of Representatives
column3: the lower chamber of the Philippine Congress)
column4: and the Quezon City Reception House (the current seat of the Vice President of the Philippines). Quezon City also serves as home to the University of the Philippines Diliman—the national university—and Ateneo de Manila University.

column1: Also located in Quezon City is the Quezon Memorial Circle

column3: a 66-meter-tall mausoleum containing the remains of President Quezon and his wife
column4: First Lady Aurora Quezon. The shrine is considered Quezon City's foremost landmark and is depicted in its city seal.

column5: and La Loma; and Diliman which consisted of Diliman proper
column6: Cubao
column7: and the University District. In 1945

column9: Philippine Commonwealth Army
column10: and Philippine Constabulary
column11: with help from recognized guerrilla units
column12: liberated and recaptured Quezon City in a few months
column13: expelling Imperial Japanese forces.  Heavy fighting occurred near Novaliches
column14: which at that time was in Caloocan
column15: and New Manila which was a strongpoint.  Smaller actions were fought at Barrio Talipapa and the University District.  Toward the end of the Battle of Manila
column16: Pres. Sergio Osmeña dissolved the Greater Manila Complex
column17: which included the Japanese-created districts of Balintawak and Diliman which had been formed from the prewar Quezon City.

column1: Quezon City is the first local government in the Philippines with a computerized real estate assessment and payment system. The city government developed a database system in 2015 that contains around 400

column2: President Quezon made a decision to push for a new capital city. Manila was getting crowded
column3: and his military advisors (reportedly) told him that Manila
column4: being by the bay
column5: was an easy target for bombing by naval guns in case of attack–a real possibility in the late 1930s. Military advisers
column6: however
column7: did not anticipate aerial bombardment.Quezon supported the idea of a new city at least 15 km (9 mi) away from Manila Bay (beyond the reach of naval guns). He contacted William E. Parsons
column8: American architect and planner
column9: who had been the consulting architect for the islands early in the American colonial period. Parsons came over in the summer of 1939 and helped select the Diliman (Tuason) estate as the site for the new city. Unfortunately
column10: he died later that year
column11: leaving his partner Harry Frost to take over. Frost collaborated with Juan Arellano
column13: and landscape architect and planner Louis Croft to craft a grand master plan for the new capital.The plan was approved by the Philippine authorities in 1941. The core of the new city was to be a 400-hectare (990-acre) central green
column14: about the size of New York's Central Park
column17: East and West Avenues. On one corner of the proposed Diliman Quadrangle was delineated a 25-hectare (62-acre) elliptical site. This was to contain a large capitol building to house the Philippine Legislature and ancillary structures for the offices of representatives.On either side of the giant ellipse were supposed to have been the new Malacañan Palace on North Avenue (site of the present-day Veterans Memorial Hospital)
column18: and the Supreme Court Complex along East Avenue (now the site of East Avenue Medical Center). The three branches of government were to be finally and efficiently located in close proximity to each other.

column1: The city lies on the Guadalupe Plateau
column2: a relatively high plateau at the northeast of the metropolis situated between the lowlands of Manila to the southwest and the Marikina River Valley to the east. The southern portion is drained by the narrow San Juan River and its tributaries to Pasig River
column3: while running in the northern portions of the city is the equally-narrow Tullahan River.

column1: Quezon City is bordered by Manila to the southwest
column2: by Caloocan and Valenzuela City to the west and northwest. To the south lie San Juan and Mandaluyong
column3: while Marikina and Pasig border the city to the southeast. To the north across Marilao River lies San Jose del Monte in the province of Bulacan
column4: while to the east lie Rodriguez and San Mateo
column5: both in the province of Rizal.

column1: The increase in the population of the city has been dramatic considering that it was only founded/consolidated (and sparsely populated) in 1939. Quezon City became the biggest city in terms of population in the Philippines in 1990 when it finally surpassed the number of inhabitants of the densely populated City of Manila. Quezon City's population continued to increase and went on to become the first Philippine city (and as of 2017 the only city) to reach 2 million people (in the late 1990s). The population is projected to reach 3 million people between the 2015 and 2020 census years and 4 million people between the 2025 and 2030 census years.The trend is also seen in the significant increase in the percentage share of Quezon City to the total population of what is now called Metro Manila. Its share comes from a low of less than 10% in the 1950s to 21.0% in 1980 and then to 22.8% in 2015.

Quezon City is predominantly Roman Catholic with roughly 90% affiliation in the population; Novaliches Diocese had a 90% Roman Catholic adherence while the Diocese of Cubao had a Roman Catholic adherence of more than 88% (Catholic Diocese Hierarchy
column3: Quezon City was made an episcopal see for two new Catholic dioceses: Cubao and Novaliches
column4: as the very populous Archdiocese of Manila was carved up and five new dioceses created.A number of religious orders have set up convents and seminaries in the city. Various Protestant faiths have seen a significant increase in membership over recent decades and are well represented in Quezon City. While the Islamic faith has its largest concentrations in the south of the Philippines
column5: there is a significant population in Quezon City. The Salam compound in Barangay Culiat houses one of the area's landmark mosques. Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) the second-largest Christian denomination in the country
column6: also has a large number of adherents with their large central temple in the city.

column1: Like other cities in the Philippines
column2: Quezon City is governed by a mayor and vice mayor elected to three-year terms. The mayor is the executive head and leads the city's departments in executing the city ordinances and improving public services. The vice mayor heads the legislative council consisting of 24 members. These councilors represent the six (6) legislative districts of the city. The council is in charge of formulating and enacting the city.
being a part of the Metro Manila region
column3: has its mayor in the Metro Manila Council headed by the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA). This council formulates development plans that seek to solve the problems and improve the conditions in the metropolis.

column1: President Manuel L. Quezon acted as mayor from October 12 to November 4
column3: pending the resignation from another position of his intended appointee
column4: Tomas B. Morato. Since a president can
column5: under Philippine law
column6: hold multiple portfolios inferior to his office
column7: Quezon took the position of mayor in a concurrent capacity. However
column8: it is erroneous to view him as the first mayor
column9: as a president holding a concurrent position is not listed in the roster of incumbents for those offices.

column1: South Triangle (the area bounded by Quezon Avenue (R-7)

Most Filipino entertainment shows and movies are produced here

column1: Several of the streets in the surrounding area were named in honor of the 22 Boy Scouts who died in a plane crash en route to joining the 11th World Scout Jamboree. A memorial stands in the center of a rotunda at the intersection of Timog and Tomas Morato Avenues
column2: which accounts for the Timog area being called the 'Scout Area'. Near the scouting memorial is the location of the former Ozone disco

column2: one of the tallest city halls in the country
column3: is located along the Circle. Surrounding the city hall are spacious parks and open areas. The head offices of some national government agencies are located in Diliman. Near the Circle are many important health centers and institutions. Along East Avenue stand the Philippine Heart Center
column4: the East Avenue Medical Center (EAMC)

column6: and the Philippine Mental Health Association. Connecting with East Avenue is Victoriano Luna Avenue where the Armed Forces of the Philippines Medical Center is located. Along North Avenue is the Veterans Memorial Medical Center (VMMC) and the Philippine Medical Association. The Philippine Children's Medical Center and Lung Center of the Philippines are located along Quezon Avenue (R-7).

It has a land area of 3 hectares and has a gross floor area of an approximate 133
column3: 327 square meters. The mall opened to the public on September 28

column1: One of the vast areas in the Galas-Santol area is the Quezon Institute compound which was originally the site of Q.I. Hospital for tuberculosis stricken patients. The hospital was established under the auspices of the Philippines Tuberculosis Society. As of 2015
column2: a large portion of the compound have ceased to form part of the hospital which remained operational up until now facing E. Rodriguez Avenue between Banawe and G. Araneta Avenue.

Araneta Avenue which allows motorist either to traverse Santol Road to exit at Ramon Magsaysay or going straight to exit either going to Balic-Balic
column2: Manila or going to E. Rodriguez or Quezon Avenue and Santa Mesa Heights area near Mabuhay (previously Welcome) Rotonda.

column1: Novaliches was named after the Marquis of Novaliches

column3: born in Granada
column4: the general who protected Queen Isabella of Spain from her uncle Don Carlos who tried to usurp the Spanish crown
column5: and supporter of her son
column6: King Alfonso
column7: upon the monarchy's restoration. He was made the first Marquis of Novaliches / Marqués de Novaliches
column8: a title bestowed with Grandeza de España (Grandee of Spain--- first class rank among the nobility)
column9: in the 1840s. Novaliches or New Liches came from an old district ( also known as pedania) of Valencia

column11: an arid mountainous trail long used by military squadrons into Jerica and Castellon

column2: he was the count-consort and second husband of the first Countess of Santa Isabel

column8: Pampanga --- descendant of Pedro Sánchez de Tagle
column9: 2nd Marquis of Altamira also known as the father of Tequila

column12: general Pavia is a great grand-uncle eight times removed to the now reigning Spanish Filipina marchioness of Griñón.  Meanwhile
column14: Santiago Matossian y Falcó now holds capitan general Pavia's wife's title as Count of Santa Isabel

column1: Novaliches is Quezon City's northernmost district and is primarily residential straddled by the La Mesa Watershed Reservation
column2: at its northeastern flank.  The La Mesa Dam supplies much of northern Metro Manila's water supply. Adjacent to the watershed is the La Mesa Watershed and Eco-Park
column3: Metro Manila's only forest.  This is the former location of President Elpidio Quirino's simple retirement house and where he tended his little tumana or vegetable garden
column4: being an Ilocano.  Quirino was very fond of the morning fog amidst the trees of Novaliches
column5: as well as hunting wild boars that used to roam the La Mesa Dam and Reservoir.  It is also the site where the president died of a heart attack. Located in the park are convention centers
column6: picnic areas
column7: swimming pools
column8: an orchidarium
column9: and a large lagoon for boating activities. It was the site of the rowing and dragon boat events for the 2005 Southeast Asian Games.

column1: Novaliches Cathedral (Cathedral Shrine and Parish of the Good Shepherd)
column2: is the seat of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Novaliches

column2: locally referred to as Bayan by residents of today and Poblacion during the American Commonwealth period before World War 2
column3: has always been the economic powerhouse of the area and the gateway to Caloocan and further more to Valenzuela.  It was a stop over point by revolutionaries for supplies in what was then a sparsely inhabited and densely forested Caloocan.  Today

column1: Barangay Santa Monica (trasl:  Barrio of Saint Monique) is mostly residential with smaller cuts of land.  The back portion of Geneva Gardens subdivision of the Neopolitan estate is the boundary marker between Barangay Santa Monica and Barangay North Fairview.  It is shaped by the Tullahan river at its lower elevation where excess water from the La Mesa dam course through.  During the monsoon season
column2: this area becomes prone to flooding.

The seeds were brought by the family while travelling from Spain to the Philippines via the Suez Canal aboard one of the many passenger ships owned by "La Compania Maritima de Filipinas".  None of these trees survive today.  The property is now the Fairview Terraces Ayala.

column7: and the UERMMMC College of Medicine (independent but related to the University of the East). While it is located in Pasig
column8: the Ateneo School of Medicine and Public Health (a constituent unit of the Ateneo de Manila University) lies close to its border with Quezon City.

column1: Other professional schools include the University of the Philippines College of Law (a constituent unit of UP Diliman) and the New Era University College of Law
column2: both located in Diliman.

column1: The Technological Institute of the Philippines specializes in engineering and vocational education.
The city government operates the Quezon City Polytechnic University
column2: which has campuses in Novaliches
column3: Batasan Hills
column4: and Barangay Santo Cristo. The Polytechnic University of the Philippines operates an extension campus in Barangay Commonwealth.

column1: Business and management schools located in the city include Entrepreneurs School of Asia located in Libis and National College of Business and Arts (NCBA) with campuses in Fairview and Cubao.
Other colleges include Far Eastern University – FERN College (independent but related to Far Eastern University)
column2: Kalayaan College
column3: the Central Colleges of the Philippines
column4: Philippine Rehabilitation Institute
column5: the main branch of the AMA Computer University
column6: and numerous campuses of information technology colleges such as Asia School of Arts & Sciences (ASAS)
column7: Informatics International College
column8: and STI College.

column1: Women's colleges such as Miriam College
column2: Immaculate Heart of Mary College
column3: and Saint Pedro Poveda College are located within city limits
column4: with the last straddling the border of Quezon City and Pasig.

column1: The Catholic K-12 schools operated by religious orders include Angelicum College (Dominican)
column2: Ateneo Grade School and High School (Jesuit)
column3: School of the Holy Spirit (Missionaries Sisters Servants of the Holy Spirit)
column4: Siena College of Quezon City (Dominicans)
column5: St. Joseph's College of Quezon City (Franciscan)
column6: Lourdes School of Quezon City (Franciscan Capuchin)
column7: St. Mary's College of Quezon City (Religious of the Virgin Mary)
column8: St. Theresa's College of Quezon City (Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary)
column9: and Stella Maris College (Dominican). Other Catholic schools operated by laypersons include Miriam College (formerly of the Maryknoll Sisters)
column10: St. Bridget School
column11: Colegio de San Lorenzo
column17: and Sacred Heart Academy of Novaliches
column18: while parochial schools include the Immaculate Conception Cathedral School in Cubao and the Good Shepherd Cathedral School in Fairview.

column1: Other private religious schools include New Era University (Iglesia Ni Cristo)
column2: Grace Christian College (evangelical Christian)
column3: Jubilee Christian Academy (evangelical Christian)
column4: Bethel Christian School of Fairview
column5: Inc. & Bethel Christian School of Holy Spirit
column6: Inc. (evangelical Christian) and Trinity University of Asia (Episcopalian).

column1: Notable secondary public schools include the Quezon City Science High School
column2: Commonwealth High School
column3: Ernesto Rondon High School
column4: Don Alejandro Roces Sr. Science-Technology High School
column5: Batasan Hills National High School
column6: the University of the Philippines Integrated School
column7: and Philippine Science High School Main Campus. The last two are operated independently of the Division of City Schools
column8: with UPIS being managed by the UP College of Education and PSHS being run by the Department of Science and Technology.

column1: Research institutes in the city include the Philippine Heart Center
column2: National Kidney and Transplant Institute
column3: the Lung Center of the Philippines
column4: the Philippine Nuclear Research Institute
column5: and the Philippine Institute for Pure and Applied Chemistry. OB Montessori Center in Fairview
column6: Quezon City is a school campus provided in Quezon City.

column1: Quezon City is the setting for much of F.H. Batacan's novel Smaller and Smaller Circles.
